metadata.case_name: Anant Prasad Lakshminivas Generiwal v. State of Andhra Pradesh & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 140 of 1962 / Petition No. 86 of 1960

facts.text: Ancestor of appellant migrated to Hyderabad in early 19th century, built temple of Shri Sitaram Maharaj Sansthan and subsidiary deity Shri Varadarajaswami at Sitaram Bagh in 1833 for two lakhs rupees, consecrated for public benefit.

In 1841, Maharaja Chandulal granted jagir of villages Akolee and Bordee in Berar for upkeep of temple; later resumed and replaced by other villages; in 1850, village Bulgaon granted; Akolee continued in possession.

In 1853, Berar transferred to British Government; in 1859, enquiries under Berar Inam Rules confirmed temple's title; inam certificates issued to Ramlal, Manager of Shri Sitaramji Maharaj of Akolee and Bulgaon for charitable expenses of temple.
Twentieth century litigation: In 1932-1933, Lakshminivas Generiwal (father of appellant) decided as manager of jagirdar, confirmed by Governor of Central Provinces.
Government of Hyderabad sought accounts; decided Central Provinces responsible; in 1941, Hyderabad accepted this.

Post-1950, Madhya Pradesh succeeded Central Provinces; MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act No.1 of 1951 took over villages, awarded compensation, sanctioned annual cash grant Rs.8,470/-; trustee realized Rs.1,30,000/- from home farm land.
Hereditary pujaris and mahants complained of misappropriation and neglect by Lakshminivas; in 1951, three pujaris complained to Hyderabad Government.
Home Minister inquired, directed five-person committee to manage temple with consent of Lakshminivas; later Lakshminivas contested consent.
One pujari filed petition under s.3 Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920 before City Civil Court Hyderabad for accounts; March 1956 court directed rendition, auditor found gross irregularities.
June 1955, temple registered as public trust under s.7(1) MP Public Trusts Act No.30 of 1951 by Registrar.
Hyderabad Endowments Regulations 1940 in force; defines endowment, trustee; ss.3-18 provide for Book of Endowments, management etc.; 478 rules framed.
Sept 12, 1957: Director of Endowments notice to Lakshminivas to show cause why removed as trustee, six charges.
Sept 17, 1957: Lakshminivas replied he no longer trustee, appellant appointed under MP Act by Deputy Commissioner Amravati Nov 1956, denied charges.
Dec 31, 1957: Notice to appellant to register temple under Regulations, warned if not, property taken under Govt supervision.
Feb 1, 1958: Appellant objected, contended MP registration excludes, no jurisdiction over endowment property.

Feb 3, 1958: Appellant filed writ petition in AP High Court challenging Dec 31 notice; contentions: MP registration final excludes Regulations; comity of nations; acquiescence; invalid under Arts 14,19. Dismissed Mar 18, 1960.
June 13, 1960: Director order, trustee failed to appear post HC judgment, take supervision under r.179.
June 14, 1960: Order taking temple under Govt supervision, management vests in Director of Endowments.
Writ petition in SC under Art.32 against June orders, challenging Regulations ultra vires Arts14,19; orders not justified.

legal_issues.text: Whether registration under MP Public Trusts Act No.30/1951 excludes operation of Hyderabad Endowments Regulations on temple situate in Andhra Pradesh.
Whether Regulations repealed by Part B States Laws Act 1951.
Whether Regulations repugnant to Art.14 due to differing laws in parts of Andhra Pradesh.
Whether Regulations and rules repugnant to Art.19(1)(f).
Whether orders of June 13/14, 1960 justified under Regulations.

petitioner_arguments.text: Registration under s.7 MP Act No.30/1951 excludes Regulations; no jurisdiction over property outside AP.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: MP Public Trusts Act No.30/1951 s.7; State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi (distinguished)

petitioner_arguments.text: Regulations repealed by Part B States Laws Act s.6 upon extension of Charitable Endowments Act 1890 and Charitable Religious Trusts Act 1920.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Part B States Laws Act No.III/1951 s.6

petitioner_arguments.text: Two different laws in two parts of AP discriminate, violative of Art.14.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.14; State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji

petitioner_arguments.text: Regulations and rules infringe Art.19(1)(f), esp. registration, removal provisions.
June 13/14 orders invalid: no inquiry, wrong authority, not under r.179 or s.12; r.67 requires inquiry.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations ss.12,4(b); Rules r.67,68,179

respondent_arguments.text: Regulations apply as temple situate in AP; some property and offerings in Hyderabad; MP registration no bar.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations; State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi

respondent_arguments.text: Regulations not repealed; Charitable Endowments Act excludes religious trusts; Charitable Religious Trusts Act limited scope.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Charitable Endowments Act 1890; Charitable Religious Trusts Act 1920

respondent_arguments.text: Differences in laws due to historical reasons, geographical classification valid under Art.14.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.14; Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of MP

respondent_arguments.text: Regulations impose reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5) for public benefit.
Orders under r.179, s.4(b), s.12 to preserve property due to non-appearance, complaints, evasion.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations ss.4(b),12; Rules r.179

court_reasoning.text: Temple situate in AP, Regulations apply even if properties outside; MP Act applies only to trusts in MP; comity no bar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where trust situate in State, law applies though properties outside; follows Charusila Dasi.

court_reasoning.text: Regulations not repealed: 1890 Act excludes religious trusts; 1920 Act limited to accounts, not comprehensive like Regulations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No corresponding law repeal under s.6 Part B Act.

court_reasoning.text: Differences historical, geographical classification valid; follows Bhaiyalal Shukla, distinguishes Rao Manohar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parallel laws in parts of State sustainable.

court_reasoning.text: Registration provisions (ss.3-11 except 4(b)) reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5) for efficient management.
June orders amount to removal without inquiry by competent officer, not by Minister, reason not under r.67; ultra vires even if constitutional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.12 requires trustee 'found incompetent' after inquiry; r.67 mandates inquiry, notice.

holdings.text: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations apply to temple situate in AP despite MP registration and external properties.
Regulations not repealed by Part B States Laws Act.
Registration provisions valid under Art.19(1)(f) read with 19(5).
June 13/14 1960 orders set aside as ultra vires Regulations.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Smt. Charusila Dasi
precedents_cited.relevance: State law applies to trust situate in State despite external properties.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Bhabapritananda Ojha
precedents_cited.relevance: State can legislate on trusts situate in State with external properties.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji
precedents_cited.relevance: Discrimination where no parallel law in other parts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Historical geographical classification valid under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narayan Pershad v. State of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Some rules struck down by Hyderabad HC.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Endowments Regulations 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs endowments; registration valid; s.12 limits removal; orders ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Public Trusts Act No.30 of 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration does not exclude AP Regulations as trust situate in AP.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act No.1 of 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Villages taken over, cash grant sanctioned.

statutes_cited.name: Charitable and Religious Trusts Act No.14 of 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Limited to accounts; does not repeal Regulations.

statutes_cited.name: Part B States (Laws) Act No.III of 1951

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court order upholding Dec 31, 1957 notice dismissed with costs; writ petition allowed, June 13/14 1960 orders set aside as ultra vires Regulations for lack of inquiry and improper authority.

key_quotes.text: "where the trust is situate in a particular State, the law of that state, will apply to the trust, even though any part of the trust property... is situate outside the state"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on territorial application of trust laws.

key_quotes.text: "These Regulations are clearly reasonable restrictions in the interests of the general public within the meaning of Art. 19(5)"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "no trustee shall be removed from trusteeship unless an inquiry is held by a competent officer"
key_quotes.speaker: court
